children.subject: jk I didn't read carefully, my bad. What courses (in particular, CV) have you taken?
the only courses i have taken that are possibly related to CV are ee16a/16b, 184, and 188.

Yes, those classes are pretty relevant! I think 126, 127 and 189 will be essential for this field, but seeing that you only have so many classes you can take in 2 semesters, I feel like 127 will be a good choice.
182 will also be a good class AFTER 189.
In which direction are you leaning towards? For grad school. General guidelines are foundational theoretic courses like 120, 126, 127, 170 and a few math courses will help you in the long run.

history.content:
Hi,

I was in a similar (almost the same) position last year so I hope I can offer some helpful advice on this. I was applying for PhD programs in robotics and machine learning. I never took CS 170. I focused on research and took other courses that were relevant to my research interests (control, optimization, math, statistics, machine learning).

I was worried that this would adversely affect my application, but it worked out for me. I cannot speak for the admissions committees, so I am just speculating based on conversations with students/professors on the committees: I don't think not taking CS 170 was made a significant difference in the decisions. I also don't think any application requires certain classes but I believe can definitely strengthen your application in certain areas.

I was also worried that I would lack the proper foundations in algorithms since I have just been learning on the fly by myself. However, as I have learned from many professors and current/former PhD students whom I look up to, a big part of grad school is learning how to teach yourself :)

Please feel free to email me if you have any other questions.

I am a rising senior interested in grad school for robotics/computer vision. My current schedule next semester consists of 61c and 170 + non-tech elective. I have taken some upper div CS classes and am familiar with C so 61c shouldn't be a problem.

However, I know 61c and 170 is high workload and it would probably be a bad idea to take a 3rd technical with it.

What I am struggling with right now is that I am really really interested in EECS106a(introduction to robotics), and idk if i should swap 170 with it. If I swap, would that be detrimental to my graduate school opportunities (since many graduate schools seem to recommend/require an algorithms course?)

My swapped schedule would be

Fall 2019: 61c + EECS106a + EE120

Spring 2020: 170+ 1/2 CS upper divs
history.subject: Interested in grad school, but haven't taken 170 yet
